titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
Thursday May 3. 1792. The evenings grow very short; and from a variety of circumstances, which upon different circumstances call me away I spend very few of them at my office, and of course have seldom an opportunity to amuse myself with this scribbling. In looking back upon the time elapsed since the date of the last pages I cannot pride my self upon a very diligent improvement of my time. A session of the Court of Common pleas has been held during the interval which required my attention, though it furnished me but little employment. My legal reading has been principally confined to Espinasse, as I have not had occasion to examine any particular Question. This day however Dr: Jennison called on me, and had some conversation with me, which induces me to enquire into the detail of the laws respecting Executors & Administrators; upon which subject, I intend to commence to-morrow morning. The professional studies are tedious: they require some certain object, some focus upon which to collect the rays of application— I have at length gone through all the philippics, which I finished yesterday. They afford some insight into the manners and habits, as well as into the History of those times, and contain many Sentiments which must be equally applicable in every period of the world.— They exhibit also a very striking figure of an unnatural state of parties and an unaccountable mixture of opposite characters connected together by a very peculiar juncture of affairs. The Coalition between the Caesarean party headed by Octavius and the Consuls Hirtius and Pansa, with the republicans, their support of the two Brutus’s & Cassius and Cicero himself, against the followers of Antony who likewise professed himself the avenger of Caesar’s murder, is very easily accounted for upon the principles of political ambition; but Cicero surely could never imagine that parties so discordant in their nature could remain united till the accomplishment of the great object, which he seems to have had in view, the re-establishment of the republic. The death of the two Consuls at and immediately after the battle at Modena was at the time considered as so extremely favourable to the view of Augustus, that it was attributed to his contrivance, and was supposed
to have been produced by treachery. But had they lived, the Event could not have been other than it was. They had been the creatures of Caesar, and their reconciliation with those who began upon their plan of reform by murdering him, could not be for any other purpose than to suppress the attempt of Antony, to engross to himself the unlimited Dominion, which he had so infamously offered to Caesar. The truth is, the republic was gone; the public mind, was enslaved, the Genius of Roman Liberty had expired, and all the efforts of human eloquence, and more than human virtue, were incompetent to the task of breathing anew in his nostrils the breath of life. There appears to me to be even in these philippics abundant evidence, that the evil was incurable. The temporizing expedients of the partisans apparently the warmest for the public good, the Embassy upon embassy, sent or proposed to be sent to Antony; the manifest restraint and alarm under which the Orator appears to labour from the supposed sentiments among the veteran troops even of his own party; the extravagant and unprecedented honours and dignities, which he is continually advising to heap upon Brutus, upon Cassius, upon the Consuls and particularly upon Octavius Caesar, all conspire to show clearly that all was rotten in the Commonwealth. The “venal city” had found her purchaser; and after submitting to the prostitution of Caesar’s dominion, it was in vain to think of reclaiming her to the virgin chastity of republican freedom. The historical information to be collected from these Orations is small, as they were all delivered in the course of a few months. The state of parties must be collected rather from what the orator does not express, than from what he says; rather from what appears dimly through the disguise in which his hopes and fears, endeavour to veil every thing about him, than from the statements which the policy of the time, made it proper for him to exhibit: But in no one particular, would it be more fallacious, than to apply to these discourses, or indeed to any others of Cicero, for the characters of the men who were then the principal actors upon the theatre of Life. It is not in the darkness of a passionate invective, nor in the splendor of a pompous panegyric, that we are to seek for the soft and delicate tints which distinguish and diversify the Qualities of his Enemies or of his friends. He is
never at a loss for virtues to decorate the followers of his own party, nor for shameful vices with which to load his opposers. But on the one hand, his animosity and partial prejudices, and on the other the simulation which circumstances might justify, but which, justifiable or not, is very evident, must detract exceedingly from the credit which we might give to his descriptions of Characters. The reader who would form a proper estimate of the real value to be of his sentiments on this head, should compare, what he says in these Orations respecting Caesar, with the Orations for Ligarius, for Marcellus, for Dejotarus, what he here says of L. Piso, with the Oration against him delivered nearly twenty years before, beginning—jamne vides bellua &c—what he says in short of all the personages introduced with his opinions relative to the same persons contained in the familiar Epistles, and after making the comparison, whatever his opinion may be of the speakers eloquence, he will not consider these compositions as the most favourable specimens of his Sincerity.— Many reflections have occurred to me during the persual of these books, but ideas like all else pertaining to this world, and perhaps even beyond the common proportion are fleeting and irretrievable— They must past unrecorded, tho’ perhaps the most valuable.— But let them go.— The world will lose but little.

Friday May 4. 1792. At my office very constantly the whole day excepting about half an hour in the forenoon, upon business for my father, and a walk at dusk for my own health. It is now between 9 and 10, and I am under the common obligation to retire to the refreshment and relaxation of the body. In the forenoon I made some enquiries into the Laws relative to Executors & Administrators, & began upon that title in Bacon. Support me ye powers of Patience, through these sandy desarts of legal study, from whence I am to pick up a scanty subsistence by forcing an unnatural cultivation.— I hope to proceed upon the undertaking to-morrow. In pursuance of my Ciceronian resolution, I have in the two last afternoon’s read the four Orations against Catiline, which I used formerly to study, but which I have not read before these ten years. To say the truth I have not read them as a critic or a philosopher, and if I had, I have no time at present to communicate the result of my reflections.

Wednesday May 16th: 1792. I am not satisfied with the manner in which I employ my time. It is calculated to keep me forever fixed in that state of useless and disgraceful insignificancy which has been my lot for some years past. At an age bearing close upon 25, when many of the characters who were born for the benefit of their fellow creatures have rendered themselves conspicuous among their cotemporaries, and founded a reputation upon which their memory remains and will continue to the latest posterity, at that period I still find myself as obscure as unknown to the world, as the most indolent, or the most stupid of human beings. In the walks of active life, I have done nothing. Fortune indeed, who claims to herself a large proportion of the merit which exhibits to public view the talents of professional men at an early period of their Lives, has not hitherto been peculiarly indulgent to me. But If to my own mind I enquire whether I should at this time be qualified to receive and derive any benefit from an opportunity which it may be in her power to procure to me, my own mind would shrink from the investigation— My heart is not conscious of an unworthy ambition; nor of a desire to establish either fame honour or fortune upon any other foundation, than that of desert.— But it is conscious, and the consideration is equally painful and humiliating, it is conscious that the ambition is constant, and unceasing, while the exertions to acquire the talents which ought alone to secure the reward, of Ambition, are feeble, indolent, frequently interrupted, and never pursued with an ardor equivalent to its purposes. My future Fortunes in Life, are therefore the objects of my present Speculation, and it may be proper for me to reflect further upon the same subject, and if possible to adopt some Resolutions, and prescribe to myself some regulations which may enable me as uncle Toby Shandy said of his miniature sieges, to answer the great ends of my existence.

First then, I begin, with establishing as a fundamental principle upon which all my subsequent pursuits and regulations are to be established, that the acquisition, at least of a respectable reputation is (subject to the overruling power and wisdom of Providence) within my own power. And that on my part nothing is wanting, but a constant, and persevering determination to tread in the steps which naturally lead to
honour. And at the same time, I am equally convinced, that I never shall attain that credit in the world, which my Nature directs me to wish, without such a steady, patient and persevering pursuit of the means adapted to the end I have in view, as has often been the subject of my speculation, but never of my practice.

lg.l: “Labour and Toil, stand stern before the throne,
And guard, so Jove commands, the sacred place.”

div.p: The mode of Life, adopted almost universally by my cotemporaries and equals, is by no means calculated to secure the objects of my ambition. My Emulation is seldom stimulated, by observing the Industry and application of those whom my situation in Life gives me for companions. The pernicious and childish opinion, that extraordinary Genius, cannot brook the slavery of plodding over the rubbish of antiquity (a cant so common among the heedless votaries of indolence) dulls the edge of all industry, and is one of the most powerful ingredients in the Circean potion, which transforms many of the most promising young men into the beastly forms, which in sluggish idleness feed upon the labours of others.— The degenerate Sentiment I hope will never obtain admission in my mind, and if my Time should be loitered away in stupid laziness, it will be under the full conviction of my conscience, that I am basely bartering the greatest benefits with which human beings can be indulged; for the miserable gratifications which are hardly worthy of contributing to the enjoyments of the brute creation.

And as I have grounded myself upon the principle, that my character is (under the smiles of Heaven) to be the work of my own hands, it becomes necessary for me to determine, upon what part of active or of speculative life, I mean to rest my pretensions to eminence— My own Situation and that of my Country equally prohibit me from seeking to derive any present expectations from a public career.— My disposition is not military; and happily the warlike talents are not those which open the most pleasing or the most reputable avenue to fame.— I have had some transient thoughts of undertaking some useful litterary performance, but the pursuit would militate at present too much, with that of the profession upon which I am to
to depend, not only for my reputation, but for my subsistence. I have therefore concluded, that the most proper object of my present attention, is that profession itself. And in acquiring the faculty to discharge the duties of it, in a manner suitable to my own wishes and to the expectations of my friends, I find ample room for close and attentive application; for frequent and considerate observation, and for such benefits of practical experience as occasional opportunities may throw in my way.

The abilities requisite to constitute the character of a great lawyer, may be traced in the labours which in the course of his profession, he is called upon to perform. These may be divided with us into two classes. The business of his office, and the business he transacts in Court. A long, painful, and incessant attention to the prescriptions of positive Law (by which I mean in general the municipal Laws) is absolutely necessary, to qualify him for giving proper advice, for doing thorough justice to his clients, as a counsellor, and for preparing the causes which are to be litigated in the Courts.
